Journal.Title: The Science of the total environment

Article.ArticleTitle: Tropospheric ozone rapidly decreases root growth by altering carbon metabolism and detoxification capability in growing soybean roots.

AbstractText: High tropospheric ozone (O<sub>3</sub>) concentrations lead to significant global soybean (Glycine max) yield reductions. Research concerning O<sub>3</sub> impacts on soybean has focused on the contributions of above-ground tissues. In this study, Mandarin (Ottawa) (O<sub>3</sub>-sensitive) and Fiskeby III (O<sub>3</sub>-tolerant) soybean genotypes provide contrasting materials to investigate O<sub>3</sub> effects on root growth. We compared root morphological and proteomic changes when 16-day-old plants were treated with charcoal-filtered (CF) air or elevated O<sub>3</sub> (80 ppb O<sub>3</sub> for 7 h/day) in continuously stirred-tank reactors (CSTR) for 7 days. Our results showed that in Mandarin (Ottawa), decreased expression of enzymes involved in the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle contributes to reduction of root biomass and diameter under elevated O<sub>3</sub>. In contrast, O<sub>3</sub> tolerance in Fiskeby III roots was associated with O<sub>3</sub>-dependent induction of enzymes involved in glycolysis and O<sub>3</sub>-independent expression of enzymes involved in the ascorbate-glutathione cycle. We conclude that a decreased abundance of key redox enzymes in roots due to limited carbon availability rapidly alters root growth under O<sub>3</sub> stress. However, maintaining a high abundance of enzymes associated with redox status and detoxification capability contributes to overall O<sub>3</sub> tolerance in roots.
